[[File:Kearny Street Workshop.jpg|thumb|Silkscreen artist and former executive director Nancy Hom takes artwork out of the International Hotel a day after the hotel's tenants were evicted]]
'''Kearny Street Workshop''' (KSW) in [[San Francisco]], [[California]], is the oldest multidisciplinary arts [[Nonprofit organization|nonprofit]] addressing [[Asian Pacific American]] issues. The organization's mission is to produce and present art that enriches and empowers Asian Pacific American communities. Notable participants include author and Asian American studies scholar [[Russell Leong]], playwright and author [[Jessica Hagedorn]], author [[Janice Mirikitani]], poet and historian [[Al Robles]], and actor and filmmaker [[Lane Nishikawa]].
== History ==
=== Origins === Kearny Street Workshop was founded as an artists' collective in 1972 in the [[International Hotel (San Francisco)|International Hotel]] (I-Hotel) on San Francisco's [[Kearny Street]]. The founders Jim Dong, Lora Joh Foo, and Mike Chin and other early leaders were involved in the [[Asian American movement]], a [[Civil Rights Movement]]-inspired period of organizational and community building in the 1970s. The [[National Endowment for the Arts]] provided some initial funding through the Neighborhood Arts Program (NAP), an initiative of the [[San Francisco Arts Commission]]. Though the founders were initially distrustful of government funds, NAP liaison Bernice Bing and founder Jim Dong eventually agreed to use a $2,000 NAP grant to fund a graphics workshop for KSW participants.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/3935054|title=The art museum as educator : a collection of studies as guides to practice and policy|last=Arts.|first=Council on Museums and Education in the Visual|date=1978|publisher=University of California Press|others=Newsom, Barbara Y., Silver, Adele Z.|year=|isbn=9780520032484|location=Berkeley|pages=207|oclc=3935054}}</ref>
In its early days, KSW shared space with a dry goods store on the ground floor of the I-Hotel.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mica.edu/About_MICA/Departments_and_Services/The_Center_for_Art_Education/Community_Arts_Journal/Visions_and_Voices_of_the_I-Hotel.html|title=Visions and Voices of the I-Hotel: Urban Struggles, Community Mythologies and Creativity {{!}} MICA|last=Art|first=Maryland Institute College of|website=www.mica.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-09-19}}</ref> The organization originally focused on cultivating [[Chinese Americans|Chinese American]] arts and activism.<ref name=":0" /> However, the organization quickly expanded to cater to a multiethnic constituency, holding classes for Asian American activists and artists to practice [[photography]], [[creative writing]], and [[silkscreen printing]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Maeda|first=Daryl Joji|date=2016-06-09|title=The Asian American Movement|url=http://americanhistory.oxfordre.com/view/10.1093/acrefore/9780199329175.001.0001/acrefore-9780199329175-e-21|language=en|doi=10.1093/acrefore/9780199329175.001.0001/acrefore-9780199329175-e-21}}</ref> Within the first few years, hundreds of Bay-area students were attending classes, [[Salon (gathering)|salons]], workshops, and [[Exhibition|exhibitions]] each day.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=|title=Kearny Street Collective: Pioneering Workshop Turns 25|last=Hsuan|first=Bryan|date=September 11, 1997|work=Asianweek|access-date=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> KSW also opened Jackson Street Gallery in an adjacent I-Hotel storefront space in 1974, where Workshop members held exhibitions, poetry readings, and musical performances.<ref name=":1" />
=== Community activism === KSW played a key role in developing Asian American activist iconography during the I-Hotel anti-eviction movement. Students and other KSW members painted a block-long mural on the Jackson Street side of the I-Hotel in support of its tenants. Screenprinted posters advocating for the I-Hotel tenants' rights appeared throughout San Francisco's [[Chinatown, San Francisco|Chinatown]], [[Little Manila|Manilatown]], and [[Japantown, San Francisco|Japantown]] during the decade-long fight for the I-Hotel. Artists from KSW also aided in the anti-eviction protests by organizing [[Demonstration (protest)|rallies]], attending court hearings, hosting exhibitions on [[affordable housing]], and publishing [[poetry]] and pamphlets that depicted life in the I-Hotel.<ref name=":1" />
KSW also provided summer youth programming that was intended to provide a diversion from gang violence in Chinatown. Workshop members also spearheaded the development of the annual Hop Jok Fair, which not only promoted Asian American artwork, but introduced many low-income Chinatown residents to available social and health services.<ref name=":0" />
=== Eviction and relocation === In 1977, both residential and business tenants were evicted from the I-Hotel. The workshop's headquarters relocated to a small storefront in [[North Beach, San Francisco]]. However, this relocation separated the organization from its key communities and constituents in Chinatown and Manilatown.<ref name=":2" />
KSW was able to return to Chinatown by 1981, leasing a basement space in a hotel on Clay Street. During its time in this space, members organized the Asian American Jazz Festival as well as the Kearny Street Workshop Press.<ref name=":2" />
In 1995, KSW was incorporated as a [[501(c)(3) organization|501(c)(3)]] nonprofit organization and relocated to [[South Park, San Francisco]].<ref name=":2" />
KSW finally relocated to a gallery and performance space in San Francisco's [[South of Market, San Francisco|SoMa]] in 2006.
== Programs and exhibitions == KSW's past and present programs include a small poetry press, writers' workshops, visual arts, [[martial arts]], readings, music, gallery exhibitions, performances, and film screenings, as well as the Asian American Jazz Festival and the annual artists festival APAture.
=== Kearny Street Workshop Press === KSW's press published poetry by Bay-area Asian American authors such as Virginia Cerenio, Bob Hsiang, Jaime Jacinto, [[Genny Lim]], Lenny Limjoco, and Jeff Tagami.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://openlibrary.org/publishers/Kearny_Street_Workshop_Press|title=Publisher: Kearny Street Workshop Press {{!}} Open Library|last=OpenLibrary.org|website=openlibrary.org|language=en|access-date=2017-09-19}}</ref>
=== Asian American Jazz Festival === KSW founded the Asian American Jazz Festival (AAJF) in 1981, with the help of organizers and KSW members George Leong and Paul Yamazaki.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.firstvoice.org/asian-american-jazz-festival/|title=Asian American Jazz Festival|website=Brenda Wong Aoki & Mark Izu – Official Website|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-19}}</ref> Until it ceased production in 2006, the AAJF was the longest continuously-running jazz festival in the San Francisco area. Notable participants include [[Mark Izu]], [[Fred Ho]], [[Vijay Iyer]], and [[Kim Jin-hi|Jin Hi Kim]].
=== APAture === APAture is an annual multidisciplinary arts festival founded in 2001. Its mission is to promote emerging artists of Asian and/or Pacific Islander descent.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kearnystreet.org/apature-faq/|title=APAture FAQ|website=Kearny Street Workshop|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-19}}</ref> Notable participants include [[Gene Luen Yang]], [[Ali Wong]], [[Hasan Minhaj]], and [[Jane Kim]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kmir.com/story/36320233/kearny-street-workshop-presents-over-60-emerging-asian-pacific-american-artists-in-the-16th-annual-apature-festival|title=Kearny Street Workshop Presents Over 60 Emerging Asian Pacific American Artists in the 16th Annual APAture Festival|access-date=2017-09-19|language=en}}</ref>
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.kearnystreet.org/ kearny street] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oodjniUGGHo Video history of KSW and APAture Festival] * [https://www.library.ucsb.edu/special-collections/cema/kearny Kearny Street Workshop Archives at UCSB] *[http://www.kqed.org/epArchive/R607131830/e kqed archive]

{{about|the Korean Film Archive|other uses|Kofa (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox Korean name |img=Kofa_logo.jpg |caption=Korean Film Archive official logotype |imgwidth=100 |hangul=한국영상자료원 |hanja=韓國映像資料院 |rr=Han'guk yeongsang jaryowon |mr=Han'kuk yǒngsang charyowǒn }} The '''Korean Film Archive''' or called '''Korean Federation of Film Archives''' and '''KOFA''' is the sole film archive in [[South Korea]] with nationwide coverage. It was founded in [[Seoul]] in 1974 as a non-profit organization. In 1976 KOFA joined the [[International Federation of Film Archives]] (FIAF) as an observer, and gained its full membership of FIAF in 1985.<ref name="Doosan">{{cite web|url=http://www.encyber.com/search_w/ctdetail.php?&masterno=703468&contentno=703468 |title=한국영상자료원 Korean Federation of Film Archives 韓國映像資料院|publisher=[[Doosan Encyclopedia]] |language=Korean}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koreafilm.org/kofa/history.asp |title=Korean Film Archive |publisher=Koreafilm.org |date= |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref>
KOFA's main duties are to collect, preserve and categorize films and film-related materials, as well as to foster accessibility to its collections. Most of remaining originals and copies of Korean films are preserved in KOFA. Its main center is in [[Sangam-dong]], Seoul, with two local branch centers in [[Busan]] and [[Bucheon]], and a secondary preservation center in [[Seongnam]]. Its main center has several public facilities, including Cinematheque KOFA,<ref>http://www.koreafilm.org/theatre/schedule.asp</ref> Korean Film Museum,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.koreafilm.org/museum/introduction.asp |title=Korean Film Archive |publisher=Koreafilm.org |date= |accessdate=2010-02-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100115025259/http://www.koreafilm.org/museum/introduction.asp |archivedate=2010-01-15 |df= }}</ref> and a reference library.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koreafilm.org/library/library.asp |title=Korean Film Archive |publisher=Koreafilm.org |date= |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref> Recently KOFA has concentrated on digitization of Korean films, and has published several features of the Classic Korean Cinema DVD Collections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koreafilm.org/publica/dvds.asp |title=Korean Film Archive |publisher=Koreafilm.org |date= |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref> It also operates the most reliable online database of Korean films,<ref name="한국영화 데이터베이스 KMDB">{{cite web|url=http://www.kmdb.or.kr/eng/index.asp |title=한국영화 데이터베이스 KMDB |publisher=Kmdb.or.kr |date= |accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref> as well as an online film streaming service.<ref name="한국영화 데이터베이스 KMDB"/>
== History == It was established as a Korean film storage center in 1974 in Namsan-dong, Jung-gu, Seoul, and moved to Seocho-dong in 1990. Since 1991, it has been renamed as Korea Media Center by foundations. It was reorganized into a special corporation based on the Motion Picture Promotion Act in 2002. It built its own building in Sangam-dong, Mapo-gu in May 2007 and formally reopened in the following year. It is composed of auxiliary and restored facilities equipped with an anti-air and photo-related facility for preserving film and other materials, Cinema Tech that provides movie screening and current affairs services, and a cinema that illuminates Korean film industry through the exhibition of film related materials. It is a member of the International Federation of Film Executions (FIAF) regular members, who hosted the Federation General Meeting in Seoul in 2002. It is a public organization for cultural services under the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism in Korea government.
== Functions == KOFA serves three main duties and various kinds of referential access services: * Film Collection and Categorization * Film Preservation, Restoration and Digitization * Film Screening and Referential Services * Publication of Academic and Referential Resources * Operation of Online Databases on Korean Cinema * [http://www.koreafilm.org/english/db_sch02.asp KOFA Film Collection Search] * [[Korean Movie Database]] online
== See also == * [[International Federation of Film Archives]] * [[Cinematheque]] * [[Cinema of Korea]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}}

{{Infobox organization | name = Kulturanova | logo = Kulturanova logo.png | logo_size = 200px | type = [[Non-governmental organization]] | founded_date = 2001 | location = {{flagicon|Serbia}}[[Novi Sad]], [[Serbia]] | focus = Arts & Culture | homepage = http://www.kulturanova.org }} '''AAC Kulturanova''' (Association for Alternative Creation) is a [[Non-governmental organization|non-government]], [[Non-profit organization|non-profit]] organization aimed at popularization and affirmation of art and cultural spirit. It was founded in May 2001. in [[Novi Sad]] (the capital of [[Vojvodina]], major region in [[Serbia]]). Organization was founded as an [[umbrella organization]] for various non-formal independent art groups, individuals and young artists from Novi Sad.<ref>http://www.charity-charities.org/SerbiaMontenegro-charities/NoviSad-1464388.html</ref> Kulturanova organization focuses its development on urban youth culture and raising awareness on relevant social issues, with the vision of building creative platforms for youth of [[Novi Sad]] and region.<ref>http://www.gradjanske.org/page/youthProgram/sr/infoCenter/directory/vojvodina.html?view=organization&organizacijaId=32</ref>
==History== Association kulturanova formed in 1999. but it was 2001. when the organization officially registered. Basic idea behind the organization was to create an [[umbrella organization]] for all young people that were exhausted by the ongoing situation in Serbia [[Serbia#Dissolution of Socialist Yugoslavia and Kosovo War .281991.E2.80.931999.29|during the 1990s]].<ref name="rhiz">{{cite web|url=http://www.rhiz.eu/institution-3079-en.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720172324/http://www.rhiz.eu/institution-3079-en.html |archive-date=2011-07-20 |dead-url=yes|title=Rhiz.eu - Association kulturanova, Novi Sad|accessdate=2016-05-18}}</ref> The harsh period of [[International sanctions|sanctions]] imposed by the [[United Nations]] during the 1990s left most young artists without opportunities to show their work in cultural institutions of the time. To this day Kulturanova worked on projects in the field of arts, theatre, design, graffiti, street culture and cultural politics.<ref>http://idealist.org/if/cac/en/av/Org/122243-298</ref>
==Projects and Activities== [[File:Ursula plassnik flow festival kulturanova 2008.jpg|right|thumb|200px|[[Ursula Plassnik]], former [[Foreign Minister of Austria]] talking at the FLOW Festival of dialogue between culture and science 2008.]][[File:I think river kulturanova 2008.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Detail from the "I think river" performance in [[Novi Sad]], 2008.]]The basic categories of Kulturanova organization activities are: '''festivals/events''' (culture), '''lectures/conferences''' (human rights, youth policy) and '''workshops/seminars''' (education). Through these basic fields of work, Kulturanova tries to create more open cultural climate. It is done through promoting [[cultural diversity]] and tolerant attitude among young people. Also, organization promotes [[cultural rights]] as an integral part of [[human rights]]. Majority projects are realized through partnerships with many organizations from the region as well as from [[European union|European Union]]. Projects developed by the Kulturanova organization during the period 2001–2010 cover the field of arts, theatre, design, graffiti, street culture and cultural politics.
* '''A3.Format''' (2009) - A3.Format is a project that is realized through online collaborative platform, which is open for diverse interventions on so called "digital canvas", dimensions 29,7 x 42 cm. Concerning the theme, works created so far are varying from simple intimate messages to themes which are concerned with the issue of human rights, politics, cultural policies, economy, ecology, nature of art, etc.<ref name="a3format">{{cite web|url=http://www.a3format.org|title=A3.Format|publisher=a3format.org|accessdate=2016-05-18}}</ref><ref>http://www.kulturanova.org/eng_projekti_dizajn.php</ref><ref name="dizajnersi">{{cite web|url=http://www.dizajnersi.com/2009/07/izlozba-a3format-urban-violence/|title=izlozba-a3format-urban-violence|publisher=dizajnersi.com|accessdate=2016-05-18}}</ref> * '''Quanta''' (2009) - "Quanta" is a performance by Italian performing artist [[Nhandan Chirco]]. It is the further step of research that started with "I think river" performance on the same concept with an international team of artists.<ref>http://www.glej.si/2009/09/quanta/</ref> * '''FLOW''' (2008) - FLOW is a Festival of conversation between culture and science, organized in collaboration with Austrian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. FLOW festival in Novi Sad was announced and open by the Austrian Minister for foreign affairs [[Ursula Plassnik]].<ref name="v000642">{{cite web|url=http://v000642.vhost-vweb-02.sil.at|title=flow festival|author=M.B.Schneider|publisher=v000642.vhost-vweb-02.sil.at|date=2007-10-05|accessdate=2016-05-18}}</ref><ref>http://www.art-idea.com/programs/flow/flow.shtml</ref> * '''INTRO''' (2008) - Intro music fest hosted over 20 artists from Serbia and region during the April 26th and 27th, 2008. * '''Second Life''' (2007) - "Second life" is an international artistic project with educational dimension run by performing arts groups in collaboration with cultural institutions in [[Kosovo]], [[Serbia]] and [[Slovenia]].<ref>http://www.ledart.org.rs/artklinika/second_life.htm</ref> * '''Urban Challenge''' (2007) - "Urban Challenge" was a part of a "All different all equal" Campaign of the [Council of Europe] aimed at promoting difference, tolerance and equal opportunities. * '''Urban Art Spaces''' (2006) - Project aimed at using non-conventional spaces for cultural activities. * '''Art and Activism Caravan''' (2006)<ref name="indymedia">{{cite web|url=http://www.indymedia.org/es/2006/08/844942.shtml|title=Centro de Medios Independientes|publisher=indymedia.org|accessdate=2016-05-18}}</ref> * '''FACE''' (2005)<ref name="caleidoscop">{{cite web|url=http://www.caleidoscop.org/Members/lsundbac/news-caleidoscop/face-festival-of-alternative-creative-exchange-novi-sad-serbia/|title=face-festival-of-alternative-creative-exchange-novi-sad-serbia|publisher=caleidoscop.org|accessdate=2016-05-18}}</ref> * '''Campaign for Youth Cultural Centre in Novi Sad''' (2005)<ref name="seecult">{{cite web|url=http://www.seecult.org/node/17203|title=AKCIJA ZA OMLADINSKI KULTURNI CENTAR | SEEcult.org Portal za kulturu jugoistočne Evrope|publisher=seecult.org|accessdate=2016-05-18}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== *Kulturanova official website http://www.kulturanova.org. *EYFA European Youth for Action http://eyfa.org *SEEcult SEEcult :: Portal for South-East European Culture http://en.seecult.org/
==External links== {{Commons category|Kulturanova}} *Kulturanova official website http://www.kulturanova.org/ *Kulturanova official Facebook fanpage http://www.facebook.com/pages/Kulturanova/285259669851/ *Kulturanova official Blog http://kulturanova.tumblr.com/ *Kulturanova Vimeo page http://www.vimeo.com/kulturanova/

{{Infobox comics creator | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Lauren Eve Montgomery | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1980|5}} | nationality = American | area = Artist, Animation, Director | notable works = ''[[Legion of Super Heroes (TV series)|Legion of Super Heroes]]'', ''[[Superman: Doomsday]]'', ''[[Justice League: The New Frontier]]'', ''[[Wonder Woman (2009 film)|Wonder Woman]]'', ''[[Justice League: Crisis on Two Earths]]'', ''[[Superman/Batman: Apocalypse]]'', ''[[Batman: Year One (film)|Batman:Year One]]'', ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'', ''[[Legend of Korra]]'', ''[[Voltron: Legendary Defender]]'' | homepage = http://laurenmontgomery.deviantart.com/?rnrd=23130 }}
'''Lauren Montgomery''' (born May 1980) is an American [[film]] [[animation director]] and [[storyboard artist]]. She is noted for her storyboard work for animated television and DVD movie features. She directed the [[Wonder Woman]] animated [[Wonder Woman (2009 film)|film of the same name]],<ref name=worldsfinest>[http://www.worldsfinestonline.com/news.php?action=fullnews&id=292 World's Finest]</ref> ''[[Green Lantern: First Flight]]'',<ref>http://www.newsarama.com/film/090716-AnimatedShorts.html Retrieved 17-07-2009</ref> ''[[Superman/Batman: Apocalypse]]'', ''[[Justice League: Doom]]'', and co-directed with [[Sam Liu]] on ''[[Justice League: Crisis on Two Earths]]'' and ''[[Batman: Year One (film)|Batman:Year One]]''. She also worked on ''[[Young Justice (TV series)|Young Justice]]'' and provided storyboards for Book 3 of ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'' for [[Nickelodeon]][[Avatar: The Last Airbender|.]] In 2012, Montgomery returned to Nickelodeon and the Avatar franchise as the supervising producer and storyboard artist for the sequel series ''[[The Legend of Korra]]''.<ref>http://bryankonietzko.tumblr.com/post/17770422581/what-a-great-post-lauren-is-an-incredible-artist</ref> She is now working as an executive producer and co-showrunner on the animated series ''[[Voltron: Legendary Defender]]'' with [[Joaquim Dos Santos]].<ref>http://nerdreactor.com/2016/03/10/dreamworks-netflix-reveal-voltron-legendary-defender-showrunners/</ref>
==Early life== Lauren Montgomery became interested in drawing as a youngster and developed an interest in animation.<ref name=superherotimes>[http://www.superherotimes.com/newsarchive/004224.php Wonder Woman Interview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716164419/http://www.superherotimes.com/newsarchive/004224.php |date=2011-07-16 }} Retrieved 15-12-2008</ref> In 1998 she enrolled in the animation program at [[Loyola Marymount University]]'s School of Film and Television where she graduated in 2002.<ref name=linkedin>[http://www.linkedin.com/pub/7/2aa/5b7 Linkedin]</ref>
==Career== ===Animation=== ====Storyboards==== Montgomery got her start on the ''[[He-Man and the Masters of the Universe (2002 TV series)|He-Man and the Masters of the Universe]]''<ref name="linkedin" /> animated by [[Mike Young Productions]]. Montgomery has done storyboards for [[Animated cartoon|animated television series]]' such as ''[[Ben 10]]'' from [[Cartoon Network Studios]] as well as storyboard work for the television series ''[[Justice League Unlimited]]'', for which producer [[Bruce Timm]] praised her work as being quite versatile.<ref>http://www.movieweb.com/news/NEKhdMKOGU9lON Retrieved 06-02-2009</ref>
Montgomery has also done storyboard work for the second [[DC Universe Animated Original Movies|DC Universe film production]], ''[[Justice League: The New Frontier]]'', based on the [[Eisner Award]]-winning [[graphic novel]] by [[Darwyn Cooke]], ''[[DC: The New Frontier]]''. She also worked on the ''[[Next Avengers: Heroes of Tomorrow]]'' and ''[[Hulk Vs]]'' animated features, [[Marvel Comics]] properties by [[Lions Gate Entertainment]]. Moreover, she worked on the [[G.I. Joe]] features for Reel FX Creative Studios and distributed by [[Paramount Pictures]]. She has also worked on the Emmy-winning series ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'' for [[Nickelodeon]]/[[Nicktoons (TV channel)|Nicktoons]].
====Directing==== Montgomery made her directorial debut by directing several episodes of the ''[[Legion of Super Heroes (TV series)|Legion of Super Heroes]]'' series, and was one of the three directors for the [[direct-to-video]] feature film ''[[Superman: Doomsday]]'', directing the second act of the movie. In March, 2008, it was announced that she is the director for the direct-to-video [[Wonder Woman (2009 film)|''Wonder Woman'' film]] from [[Warner Premiere]]. The animated feature was released on March 3, 2009.<ref name="worldsfinest"/> Furthermore, she is the director of ''[[Green Lantern: First Flight]]'', which was released on July 28, 2009.<ref>http://www.movieweb.com/news/NEGsLPLK8ajMKJ Retrieved 12-05-2009</ref> Subsequently, Montgomery co-directed ''[[Justice League: Crisis on Two Earths]]'' (with [[Sam Liu]]) and directed ''[[Superman/Batman: Apocalypse]]''.
====Producing==== Montgomery served as a supervising producer on Nickelodeon's ''[[The Legend of Korra]]'', created by [[Bryan Konietzko]] and [[Michael Dante DiMartino]].<ref>http://bryankonietzko.tumblr.com/post/17753125873/retakes-retakes-retakes-retakes-retakes-they</ref> Previously, she provided storyboard work on [[Avatar book 3|Book 3]] for the original series ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'', also a Konietzko/DiMartino collaboration.
===Illustration=== Montgomery has released a sketchbook with comic book/animation artist Eric Canete entitled ''Beauty and the Beast'' published by Black Velvet Studios. She has also done various freelance illustration work such as illustrating a cover for ''Nickleodeon Magazine''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nickmag-comics.livejournal.com/12984.html?thread%3D108472 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090113005150/http://nickmag-comics.livejournal.com/12984.html?thread=108472 |archivedate=2009-01-13 |df= }} Retrieved 15-12-2008</ref> and a press release illustration for the ''Avatar'' series.<ref>http://notthepornstar.deviantart.com/art/Day-of-Black-Sun-Press-Art-72027790 Retrieved 15-12-2008</ref>
===Style=== According to Montgomery, "I was definitely influenced by the Disney films. Those were the drawings I was tracing and sketching during my early years. I would study each and every one of the princesses and draw them until I had them all down by heart. My facial features are still influenced somewhat by Disney characters. As I got older, I was definitely influenced by Bruce's style in Batman (referring to [[Bruce Timm]] and ''[[Batman: The Animated Series]]''), and I started getting into anime, and some of the more subtle styles in anime drawing. The clothing is a little more detailed than the typical American animation – it's more believable, yet still simplified. It's the way they draw bodies and cloth that I kind of incorporate into my drawings, as well as certain aspects of how they would draw hair. So I'd say I have a few different influences in my art style."<ref name="superherotimes"/>

{{Infobox school | name = Leonardo da Vinci Art School | image = Paintings-Murals-Conrad A. Albrizio-titled "The New Deal"-dedicated to President Roosevelt-placed in the auditorium... - NARA - 196024.tif | alt = | caption = ''The New Deal'', mural by [[Conrad Albrizio]] (1934) | motto = | motto_translation = | location = 288 East 10th Street, [[New York City]], NY | country = United States of America | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | other_name = <!-- or | other_names = --> | former_name = <!-- or | former_names = --> | type = Art school | established = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | opened = December 1923 | closed = April 28, 1942 | district = | grades = | superintendent = | principal = [[Onorio Ruotolo]] | staff = | faculty = | gender = <!-- use | gender_label = to override the default label --> | age_range = <!-- or | lower_age = and | upper_age = --> | enrollment = <!-- or | enrolment = --> | campus_size = | campus_type = | team_name = | newspaper = | colors = <!-- or | colours = --> | communities = | feeder_schools = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | footnotes = }} The '''[[Leonardo da Vinci]] Art School''' (the "Leonardo") was an art school founded in [[New York City]] (1923-1942), whose most famous student was [[Isamu Noguchi]] and whose director was sculptor and poet [[Onorio Ruotolo]].<ref name= Sciorra-Vellon> {{cite journal | first1= Joseph | last1 = Sciorra | first2 = Peter | last2 = Vellon | title = Onorio Ruotolo: A Life in Art and Politics | journal = America and Italia Review | publisher = Italian American Museum | url = https://www.academia.edu/32981932/The_Art_of_Freedom_Onorio_Ruotolo_and_the_Leonardo_Da_Vinci_Art_School | pages = 2-4 | date = April 2004 | accessdate = 30 May 2018}}</ref><ref name=Herrera> {{cite book | first = Hayden | last = Herrera | title = Listening to Stone: The Art and Life of Isamu Noguchi | publisher = Farrar, Straus and Giroux | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=kyelBAAAQBAJ | pages = 68-71 | date = 21 April 2015 | accessdate = 30 May 2018}}</ref>
==History==
===First decade===
With sculptor [[Attilio Piccirilli]], Ruotolo founded the school to provide low-cost, often free art instruction to the working poor, mostly in the evening. The school was first located at [[St. Nicholas of Myra Church (Manhattan)|St. Nicholas of Myra, Christian Orthodox Church]], 288 East 10th Street, off Avenue A and near Tompkins Square Park. Tuition was six dollars ($6) per month—or free.<ref name= Sciorra-Vellon /> Students in the 1920s included Noguchi and [[Esther Shemitz]].<ref name=Herrera /><ref name=Lumpkin> {{cite book | first = Grace | last = Lumpkin | title = To Make My Bread | publisher = University of Illinois Press | place = Chicago | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Ol4ejvSpxdEC | pages = ix | date = 1932 | accessdate = 5 January 2017}}</ref>
To foster Noguchi's decision to study sculpture, Ruotolo offered him a job that paid as much as other work he had. Later, Noguchi recalled, "How could I resist? I became a sculpture even against my will." After only three months at the "Leonardoo" (as the school was known), Noguchi held a solo exhibition. Ruotolo also helped Noguchi get commissions for outside sculpture work.<ref name=Herrera />
===Second decade===
In 1934, the school reorganized and reopened at 149 East 34th Street, graced by "The New Deal" mural of [[Conrad Albrizio]].<ref> {{cite web | title = Paintings: Murals: Conrad A. Albrizio: titled "The New Deal" | publisher = National Archives | url = https://research.archives.gov/id/196024 | date = | accessdate = 14 October 2015}}</ref><ref> {{cite news | first = Robin | last = Miller | title = Baton Rouge now home to second historic Conrad Albrizio mosaic — this one saved from demolition in Algiers | publisher = The Advocate | url = http://theadvocate.com/news/13509228-123/baton-rouge-now-home-to | date = 21 September 2015 | accessdate = 14 October 2015}}</ref><ref> {{cite web | title = Conrad Albrizio | publisher = KnowLA | url = http://www.knowla.org/entry/583/ | date = | accessdate = 14 October 2015}}</ref> With political and union backing, the school expanded to include the "Friends of Italian Arts Association," eliminating tuition altogether, so that student needed provide only their own art materials. No employees received payment for their services. For the school's rededication, Mayor [[Fiorello LaGuardia]] unveiled a fresco symbolic of the New Deal.<ref name= Sciorra-Vellon />
===Closure===
Contributions diminished significantly during [[World War II]], leading to the Leonardo's closture at its third and final location at 130 East 16th Street on April 28, 1942.<ref name= Sciorra-Vellon />
==Legacy==
In addition to starting the career of Noguchi, the Leonardo also was the only school in its time to teach the art of fresco painting.<ref name= Sciorra-Vellon />

{{Infobox person | name = Lin Bolen | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|mf=yes|1941|03|21}} | birth_place = [[Benton, Illinois]] [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|mf=yes|2018|01|19|1941|03|21}} | death_place = [[Santa Monica, California]] U.S. | nationality = American | other_names = Lin Bolen Wendkos | occupation = Vice President of Daytime Programming, NBC (1972-1976)
[[Television producer]] | years_active = 1972–late 1990s | spouse = {{marriage|[[Paul Wendkos]]|1983|2009|end=d.}} | children = }} '''Lin Bolen''' (March 21, 1941 – January 19, 2018) was an American television executive and producer. She was most noted for her role at [[NBC]] [[daytime television]] [[Television programming|programming]] as the first female vice president of a TV network, a position she held from 1972 until 1976.{{cite book|last1=Lowe|first1=Denise|title=Women and American television: an encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Dc9kAAAAMAAJ|date=December 1999|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-87436-970-0|page=43|oclc=42649641}} In this role, Bolen was responsible for commissioning the long-running [[game show]] ''[[Wheel of Fortune (U.S. game show)|Wheel of Fortune]]'' and is credited with bringing successful long form to network [[soap opera]]s.{{cite book|last1=Pilato|first1=Herbie J.|title=Twitch Upon a Star: The Bewitched Life and Career of Elizabeth Montgomery|date=2012|publisher=Taylor Trade Publishing|location=Lanham, MD|isbn=978-1-589-79750-5|pages=274–275; 279|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/twitch-upon-a-star-the-bewitched-life-and-career-of-elizabeth-montgomery/oclc/825116583/viewport|oclc=825116583}} Bolen was mentioned in ''[[Marquis Who's Who|Who's Who in America]]'' as a trailblazer for women in television. == Early life and education == Bolen was born in [[Benton, Illinois]].{{cite journal|last1=Moore|first1=Sally|title=The Mistress of Daytime TV|journal=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=22 April 1974|volume=1|issue=8|url=http://people.com/archive/the-mistress-of-daytime-tv-vol-1-no-8/|language=en}} Her father was a [[United Mine Workers]] union organizer. Her sister Marilyn Bolen was notable for being the first woman stockbroker to work on the St. Louis exchange floor.{{cite news|last1=Klemesrud|first1=Judy|title=Soap Operas: Same Time, Same Station, but a New Boss|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1972/10/11/archives/soap-operas-same-time-same-station-but-a-new-boss.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=11 October 1972}} Bolen graduated from [[Benton Consolidated High School]]. She attended [[Margaret A. Hickey|Miss Hickey's School]] in [[St. Louis]]. From 1961 to 1963, she attended [[City College of New York]], where she studied advertising and communications media.{{cite news|last1=Genzlinger|first1=Neil|title=Lin Bolen, a Trailblazing TV Executive, Dies at 76|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/04/obituaries/lin-bolen-dead.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=4 February 2018}} ==Career== In 1961, Bolen began her career producing commercials. She then worked on documentaries about [[Twiggy]], and then as a writer and producer of documentary films, which included ''Crisis in America – Welfare '' for ABC-TV and ''Stravinsky's Requiem to Marin Luther King'' with the [[New York City Ballet]].{{cite news|last1=Hess|first1=Marge|title=Woman heads daytime NBC shows|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/16735722/|work=[[The Hutchinson News]]|date=15 June 1973|page=33}} {{closed access}} Bolen was appointed Vice President of Daytime Programming at NBC in 1972. In September 1975, she was the first female Vice President of Programming at a TV network and took NBC to #1 in the national [[Nielsen ratings]].{{cite news|title=NBC Takes Daytime Lead|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=22 September 1975}} She developed an expanded format for ''[[Days of Our Lives]]'' and ''[[Another World (TV series)|Another World]]'', changing both to an hour-long running time. The expanded shows attracted new viewers and became hits with young women.{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Les|title=NBC‐TV Trying an Hour‐Long Daytime Soap Opera|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1974/10/19/archives/nbctv-trying-an-hourlong-daytime-proliferation-is-noted.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 October 1974}}{{cite news|title=‘As World Turns’ on CBS Will Expand to Hour Dec. 1|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1975/09/10/archives/as-world-turns-on-cbs-will-expand-to-hour-dec1.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 September 1975}} Although NBC was airing the successful game shows ''[[Hollywood Squares]]'', ''[[Concentration (game show)|Concentration]],'' and ''[[Jeopardy!]]'' at the time, Bolen's mandate was to increase ratings of young women ages 18–34. Daytime and late-night were seen as NBC's profit center at that time, and advertisers wanted programs that attracted young women. In late 1972, Bolen ended ''Concentration'' 's fifteen-year run and replaced it with the [[Heatter-Quigley Productions]] game show ''[[Baffle (game show)|Baffle]]''. ''Baffle'' failed to compete with [[CBS]]'s new game show, ''[[The $10,000 Pyramid]]'', and was canceled on March 29, 1974. Bolen also decided to end the eleven-year run of ''Jeopardy!'', feeling that its demographics were old. The show's creator and producer [[Merv Griffin]] did not wish to change the show's format, so Bolen commissioned a new game show from Griffin called ''[[Wheel of Fortune (U.S. game show)|Wheel of Fortune]]''.{{cite book|last1=Griffin|first1=Mer|last2=Bender|first2=David (with)|title=Merv: Making the Good Life Last|date=2003|publisher=Simon & Schuster|location=New York|isbn=978-0-743-23682-9|pages=98–99|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/merv/oclc/893133089/viewport|oclc=51059113}} Two pilots were produced before the network was satisfied that young women would love the show, although Bolen risked being fired if the show failed. ''Wheel of Fortune'' debuted on January 6, 1975, and was an immediate ratings hit.{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=Les|title=TV Notes: All‐Star Game Throws Democrats a Curve; "Lucky Lady"|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1975/12/21/archives/tv-notes-allstar-game-throws-democrats-a-curve.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=21 December 1975}} In the spring of 1976, while NBC was still the #1 network in daytime, Bolen left the network to become an independent TV producer. She formed her own production company called Lin Bolen Productions. The new company created and developed game shows, movies of the week, and theatrical films for networks and studios.{{cite news|last1=Sharbutt|first1=Jay|title=New Soap Bubbles From ABC|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-06-25/entertainment/ca-10662_1_soap-operas|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=25 June 1985}} Bolen created the game show ''[[Stumpers!]]'' hosted by [[Allen Ludden]], which was produced exclusively by Bolen's production company. The show was a word game with game elements similar to ''[[Password]]'', which had also been hosted by Ludden. The show lasted 13 weeks before being canceled by new NBC president [[Fred Silverman]]. One series Bolen's company produced for NBC was loosely based on her own career, taking a serious look at the men who ran network television. ''[[W.E.B.]]'' was scheduled against [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s hit series ''[[Charlie's Angels]]'' and did not perform well. It was canceled after 13 weeks. In 1982, Bolen was hired as head of creative affairs at InterMedia Entertainment, which was owned by [[Fred Silverman]]. Bolen's company produced the television movie ''The Christmas Coal Mine Miracle'', starring [[Kurt Russell]] and [[Melissa Gilbert]], which became the highest rated movie of the year for NBC. Other films followed, including ''Good Against Evil'' starring [[Kim Cattrall]] and [[Dan O'Herlihy]] for ABC; ''Golden Gate'' starring [[Perry King]], [[Melanie Griffith]], and [[John Saxon]]; A two-hour [[television pilot|pilot]] for ABC called ''Farrell for the People'' starring [[Valerie Harper]] and [[Ed O'Neill]]; a comedy pilot for NBC called ''The [[Ann Jillian]] Show'', and an NBC summer variety pilot called ''Live From the South Seas'' starring [[John Rowles]]. ==''Network''== Bolen's career as a network executive provided an inspiration in the creation of [[Faye Dunaway]]'s role as network executive Diana Christiansen in the 1976 satirical film about television, ''[[Network (1976 film)|Network]]''.{{cite news|last1=Shales|first1=Tom|title='Network': The Prophetic Conniption|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1978/10/04/network-the-prophetic-conniption/c549faf9-a1f9-4b35-b403-0f50b349ba86/|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=4 October 1978}}{{cite book|last1=Dunaway|first1=Faye|last2=Sharkey|first2=Betsy (with)|title=Looking for Gatsby: My Life|date=1998|publisher=Pocket Books|location=New York|isbn=978-0-671-67526-4|pages=303–304|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/looking-for-gatsby-my-life/oclc/38540422/viewport|oclc=38540422}} However, in an interview with [[United Press International|UPI]] in 1978, Bolen had said that the ''Network'' character was nothing like her.{{cite news|last1=Scott|first1=Vernon|title=Producer Lin Bolen Denies She's 'Network' Character|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1368&dat=19780731&id=_HBIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7xEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6979,6011319|work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|Milwaukee Sentinel]]|agency=[[United Press International|United Press International (UPI)]]|date=31 July 1978|page=2}}{{cite news|last1=Brody|first1=Larry|title=LB: Saying Goodbye to Lin Bolen, A Real TV Pioneer|url=https://tvwriter.net/lb-saying-goodbye-to-lin-bolen/|work=TVWriter.Com|date=29 January 2018}} ==Personal life and death== After leaving NBC, Bolen married director [[Paul Wendkos]] in 1984. They remained married until his death on November 12, 2009.{{cite news|last1=Hevesi|first1=Dennis|title=Paul Wendkos, Director of ‘Gidget,’ Dies at 84|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/22/arts/television/22wendkos.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=21 November 2009}} Bolen died on January 19, 2018 at a hospital in the [[San Fernando Valley]], and was survived by her son, Jordan Wendkos.{{cite news|last1=Haring|first1=Bruce|title=Lin Bolen Dies: First Female VP Of Programming At A Network Was 76|url=http://deadline.com/2018/01/lin-bolen-dies-first-female-vp-of-programming-at-a-network-was-76-1202272021/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=28 January 2018}} == Selected filmography == * ''Crisis in America – Welfare'' * ''Stravinsky's Requiem to Marin Luther King'' * 1976: ''[[Stumpers!]]'' (TV Series) – Creator, executive producer, writer (1 episode) * 1977: ''Good Against Evil'' (TV Movie) – Executive producer * 1977: ''[[Christmas Miracle in Caufield, U.S.A.]]'' aka ''Christmas Coal Mine Miracle'' (TV Movie) – Producer * 1978: ''[[W.E.B.]]'' (TV Series) – Executive producer (3 episodes) * 1981: ''Golden Gate'' (TV Movie) – Producer * 1982: ''Farrell for the People'' (TV Movie) – Producer * 1984: ''Comedy Club'' (TV Movie) – Executive producer * 1989-1990: ''[[Ann Jillian (TV series)|Ann Jillian]]'' * ''Live From the South Seas'' == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Further reading == * {{cite book|last1=Bolen|first1=Lin|title=Six From Showbiz|date=17 May 1978|publisher=Long Beach Museum of Art Video Archive|location=Long Beach, {{Infobox person | name = Lone Scherfig | image = LoneScherfig09TIFF.jpg | caption = Scherfig at the [[2009 Toronto International Film Festival]] | occupation = [[Film director]], [[screenwriter]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|5|2|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]] }} '''Lone Scherfig''' (born 2 May 1959) is a [[Denmark|Danish]] [[film director]] and [[screenwriter]] who has been involved with the [[Dogme 95]] film movement and who has been widely critically acclaimed for several of her movies, including the Oscar-nominated film ''[[An Education]]'' (2009). Scherfig's movies are generally [[romantic comedy|romantic comedies]], including her film ''[[One Day (2011 film)|One Day]]'' (2011), based on the [[David Nicholls (writer)|David Nicholls]] novel. Through both experimenting with creative constraints and her astute attention to detail, she has come to be recognized as a blossoming talent in the film industry.{{cite news |first=Roger |last=Ebert |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20040430/REVIEWS/404300309/1023 |title=Wilbur Wants to Kill Himself |newspaper=Chicago Sun Times |date=30 April 2004 |accessdate=18 May 2012}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0Trq5MTxm0IC&lpg=PA219 |title=The Danish Directors 2: Dialogues on the New Danish Fiction Cinema |first1=Mette |last1=Hjort, |last2=Jorholt |first2=Eva |last3=Redvall |first3=Eva Novrup |year=2010 |location=Bristol |publisher=Intellect Books |isbn=978-1-84150-271-7 |accessdate=18 May 2012}} == Career == === 1980s – 1990s: Early beginnings === Scherfig graduated from the [[National Film School of Denmark]] in 1984,{{cite book |title=Kosmorama |publisher=Danske Filmmuseum |issue=v. 246 |year=2010 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F9rOpv7noMcC |access-date=February 26, 2018 |page=148}} and began her career as a director with the television film ''Margrethes elsker'' in 1985. Previously, she had been involved in the advertising business and had won awards (including the Lion d'Argent) at the Cannes International Advertising Film Festival. Her directorial debut in film came with ''Kaj's fodselsdag''. The film was critically successful and garnered her the Grand Jury prize and the Club Espace Award at the [[Rouen Nordic Film Festival|Rouen Nordic FIlm Festival]]. For a period of time following such success, Scherfig wrote and directed a few short films and worked with both radio shows and the stage. In 1998, she directed the film ''Nar mor kommer hjem'', which was the recipient of the Grand Prix at the [[Montreal World Film Festival|Montreal Film Festival]] and the Cinekid Award in [[Amsterdam]]. === 2000s: International breakthrough, ''Italian for Beginners'' === Scherfig found her international breakthrough with the film ''[[Italian for Beginners]]'' (2000), which was critically acclaimed and won several awards, including the Jury Grand Prix [[Silver Berlin Bear|Silver Bear]] award at the [[Berlin International Film Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://www.tributemovies.com/people/Lone+Scherfig/8495/ |title=Lone Scherfig Biography |work=Tributemovies.com |date=1959-05-02 |accessdate=18 May 2012}} Hailed as a feel-good movie, the film is consistently preoccupied with themes of hope, happiness, and choice. It is credited as the most profitable Scandinavian film to date.{{cite web |url=http://www.moreintelligentlife.com/blog/lucy-farmer/qa-lone-scherfig-filmmaker |last=Farmer |first=Lucy |title=The Q&A: Lone Scherfig, Filmmaker |work=MoreIntelligentLife.com |accessdate=15 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100102154337/http://moreintelligentlife.com/blog/lucy-farmer/qa-lone-scherfig-filmmaker |archivedate=2 January 2010 |df=}} The film, following the creative constraints of the [[Dogme 95]] movement, is set almost entirely on location within a small space, uses sound only found at the source, and it's shot on video. The film involves several characters and their various romantic or otherwise interactions that unfold across this limited setting. As opposed to many other ''[[Dogme 95]]'' films, Scherfig's is rather upbeat and comedic, and has been noted for its rather amusing tone.{{cite news |first=Roger |last=Ebert |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20020201/REVIEWS/202010303/1023 |title=Italian For Beginners |newspaper=Chicago Sun Times |date=1 February 2001 |accessdate=18 May 2012}} Following ''Italian for Beginners'', Scherfig made the deadpan comedy ''[[Wilbur Wants to Kill Himself]]'', released in 2002. This film, not considered a part of the ''Dogme 95'' canon, is a touching movie centered on a suicidal man who is constantly saved and cared for by his brother. Noted by critics to be a surprisingly lighthearted affair, the movie was praised for Scherfig's ability to craft deep and interesting characters. A.O. Scott mused that the film's tone "ranges from stoic to diffident to quizzical, at least on the surface. But there is an undercurrent of deep and complicated feeling beneath the Scottish reserve; it is signalled by the music, and by Ms. Scherfig's exquisite sense of nuance." {{cite news |first=A. O. |last=Scott |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9404E0DC133EF931A25750C0A9629C8B63 |title=Wilbur Wants to Kill Himself |newspaper=The New York Times |date=12 March 2004 |accessdate=18 May 2012}} This film found Scherfig working closely with the prolific writer [[Anders Thomas Jensen]] in developing a screenplay. It also allowed her to align her work with the production companies Sigma Films and Zentropa. Although well received, ''Wilbur'' was not as commercially successful as ''Italian for Beginners'', although it did act as a catalyst for a ''Dogme 95'' related project called the "Advance Party," in which both Scherfig and Jensen helped write characters for [[Lars Von Trier]]. As with ''Wilbur Wants to Kill Himself'', Scherfig wrote and directed another character focused film: ''[[Just like Home (2007 film)|Just Like Home]]'', released in 2007. In this comedic endeavour, set in a little town, several characters unite to discover who could be causing commotion in the streets at night. The movie concerns itself primarily with the various citizens of the town and their interactions with each other. In the style of constraints learned by being involved in the ''Dogme 95'', Scherfig claims that the film was written piece by piece every day it was shot.{{cite web |url=http://www.combustiblecelluloid.com/2008/justlikehome.shtml |title=Just Like Home (2008), Lone Scherfig, Lars Kaalund, Bodil Jorgensen, DVD review |work=Combustible Celluloid |date=26 April 2008 |accessdate=18 May 2012}} Further proving Scherfig's fascination with lighthearted and sweet affairs, she has claimed the story is "about trust...the fundamental belief that people you hardly know will want the best for you." {{cite web |url=http://fest08.sffs.org/films/film_details.php?id=46 |title=Just Like Home |work=San Francisco International Film Festival |date=8 May 2008 |accessdate=18 May 2012}} The film received very little commercial or critical spotlight, instead acting as a bridge between Scherfig's earlier experiments and her more American successes. === 2010s: Further success, ''An Education'' === In 2009, ''[[An Education]]'', Scherfig's most critically lauded film, was released. Written by esteemed fiction author [[Nick Hornby]], the movie was based on journalist Lynn Barber's experiences as a teenager in post-war Britain. The film's story follows 16-year-old Jenny (played by [[Carey Mulligan]]) as she is picked up one rainy night by David (played by [[Peter Sarsgaard]]), and brought into the bustling and exciting London society. Centered on this tender and somewhat morally ambiguous romantic relationship between David and Jenny, the movie was hailed as being subtle and deliberate in its pacing and tone.{{cite news |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20091021/REVIEWS/910219994 |title=An Education |work=Rogerebert.com |accessdate=18 May 2012 |date=21 October 2009}} Many reviewers noted the exceptional performance of Carey Mulligan as the protagonist.{{cite web |url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/review/an-education/4498 |title=An Education: Film Review |work=Slant Magazine |date=7 October 2009 |accessdate=18 May 2012}} She went on to gain a nomination from the Academy Awards, as did the film itself (for Best Picture) and Nick Hornby (for his Adapted Screenplay).{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1174732/awards |title=An Education: Awards |date=5 February 2010 |work=IMDb |accessdate=18 April 2017}} On making the film, Scherfig has talked about her focus on the theme of being an American teenager examined throughout the story, saying, "my guess is about America is that it’s this combination of innocence and freedom that attracts you. Here in Denmark, as well, it was more liberated than it is now, and was definitely more innocent and less dangerous. I mean, when I was a teenager, the world was a lot safer than it is now for my daughter as a teenager, which meant that I could have a lot more fun. It wasn’t risky the way it is now." She has also discussed the pleasures of working in a more collaborative spirit for this movie, commenting that the movie was "the same piece that we [were] all working on, and that was really important to me as a director that everyone was making the same film, that everyone contributed to the package and tried to strengthen it and get as many facets as possible but not be over-inventive, [to] just tell the story as well as we possibly could." {{cite web |url=http://blog.hulu.com/2009/11/17/an-education/ |title=Exclusive Interview: Director Lone Scherfig, "An Education" |first=Rebecca |last=Harper |work=Hulu.com |date=17 November 2009 |accessdate=18 May 2012}} Coming off the success of ''An Education'', Scherfig had many opportunities to develop a more expansive American career in filmmaking. Scherfig's next film titled ''[[One Day (2011 film)|One Day]]'', released in 2011, follows the lives of two romantically engaged individuals as they intersect one day each year. Based on a novel and then adapted by [[David Nicholls (writer)|David Nicholls]], the movie marks a more obvious turning point for Scherfig's career in reaching a mildly larger audience than any of her previous films. The plot and story of the movie has been commented on being somewhat simple and predictable, but critics were also aware of Scherfig's ability to give the dialogue and tone of the film a distinct freshness.{{cite news |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110817/REVIEWS/110819983 |title=One Day |first=Roger |last=Ebert |newspaper=Chicago Sun-Times |accessdate=18 May 2012 |date=17 August 2011}} Leading actors [[Anne Hathaway]] and [[Jim Sturgess]] both lent the film access to a wider audience. Scherfig herself had stated expressly her interest in working with Hathaway on this project. She has also commented on the difficulties of working with someone else's screenplay, saying in an interview that: :
It’s so much easier to work with something you’ve written, because you can cut things or add things on the spot. You can be much more at home and at ease with what you do. You don’t feel unfaithful to the writer because there is no writer. Most of the other films I’ve done I’ve co-written, and I prefer it. But having said that, when you work with someone else’s characters, you get a lot of gifts. You get an entire world, you get to portray people that you couldn’t have made up, and entire worlds that are fascinating because they are not yours. It’s much harder, I really think it’s much harder {{cite web |url=http://thescorecardreview.com/articles/interviews/2011/08/26/one-day-interview-with-director-lone-scherfig/23868 |title='One Day' interview with director Lone Scherfig |date=26 August 2011 |work=The Scorecard Review |accessdate=18 April 2017}}
[[File:Lone Scherfig, Director.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Scherfig at the 2017 [[Miami International Film Festival]]]] Ultimately, the film was a moderate success commercially, grossing over $56 million worldwide on a $15 million budget.{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1563738/ |title=One Day |date=19 August 2011 |work=IMDb |accessdate=18 April 2017}} It also furthered Scherfig's career and her capacity to reach a broader audience. Scherfig worked as a consultant writer for the Danish film ''Alting'', and has worked on other projects (such as ''[[Red Road (film)|Red Road]]'' and ''Donkeys'') in helping write and develop characters.{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0771054/ |title=Lone Scherfig |work=IMDb.com |accessdate=18 April 2017}} Her most recent work is ''[[The Riot Club]]'', based on the stage play ''[[Posh (play)|Posh]]'' by [[Laura Wade]], released in 2014. The film follows two first-year students amongst the privileged elite of Oxford University, determined to join the infamous Riot Club, where reputations can be made or destroyed over the course of a single evening. Universal Pictures distributed the film in the UK and Ireland.{{cite web |url=http://www.screendaily.com/festivals/cannes/upi-gets-posh-as-cast-gathers/5056447.article |title=Universal takes UK, Irish rights to Lone Scherfig's Posh |work=[[Screendaily]] |accessdate=18 April 2017}} == Awards and nominations == ''Kaj's fodselsdag'' won both the Club Espace Award and the Grand Jury Prize at the Rouen Nordic Film Festival in 1991. ''Nar mor kommer hjem'' won the Cinekid Film Award in 1998. At the Berlin International Film Festival, ''Italian for Beginners'' won the FIPRESCI Prize, the Prize of Ecumenical Jury, the Reader Jury of the "Berliner Morgenpost," and the Silver Berlin Bear, and was nominated for the Golden Berlin Bear. It was also nominated for a Bodil (as was ''Wilbur Wants to Kill Himself'' and ''An Education''). ''Italian for Beginners'' was nominated at the Chicago International Film Festival, the European Film Awards, the Goya Awards, and picked up awards at Bordeaux International Festival of Women in Cinema, the Festróia-Tróia International Film Festival, the Flaiano Film Festival, the Hamptons International Film Festival, the Paris Film Festival, the Robert Festival, the Valladolid Film Festival, and the Warsaw International Film Festival. ''Wilbur Wants to Kill Himself'' garnered nominations from the British Independent Film Awards, the Chlotudis Awards, the Robert Festival, the Valladolid Film Festival, and came in second place at the Emden International Film Festival. It took home awards at the Festróia-Tróia International Film Festival, the Hamptons International Film Festival, the Skip City International D-Cinema Festival, the U.S. Comedy Arts Festival, and the Victoria Independent Film & Video Festival in Canada. Although ''Just Like Home'' was shunned by critics, Scherfig's fourth film was offered the most recognition. ''An Education'' was nominated at the BAFTA Awards, the British Independent Film Awards, the European Film Awards, the Film Critics Circle of Australia Awards, the Satellite Awards, and the Academy Awards. It won various awards at the Chicago International Film Festival, the Independent Spirit Awards, the Mill Valley Film Festival, the Robert Festival, and the Sundance Film Festival.{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0771054/awards |title=Lone Scherfig: Awards |work=IMDb.com |accessdate=18 April 2017}} == Filmography == {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! [[File:Kalunga-lusona.jpg|400px|thumb|Lusona ideograph illustrating the story of the beginning of the world]]
'''Sona''' (sing. Lusona) drawing is an [[Ideogram|ideographic]] tradition known across eastern [[Angola]], northwestern [[Zambia]] and adjacent areas of the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], and is mainly practiced by the [[Chokwe people|Chokwe]] and [[Luchazi language|Luchazi]] people.{{sfn|Gerhard Kubik|2006|p=1}} These ideographs function as [[Mnemonic|mnemonic devices]] to record proverbs, fables, games, riddles and animals, and to transmit knowledge.<ref name="Elsevier BV 1991 pp. 198–198">{{cite journal | title=On mathematical elements in the Tchokwe "Sona" tradition Gerdes, Paulus. 1990. For the Learning of Mathematics10(1), 31–34 | journal=Historia Mathematica | volume=18 | issue=2 | year=1991 | issn=0315-0860 | doi=10.1016/0315-0860(91)90542-6 | url=http://webapp1.dlib.indiana.edu/virtual_disk_library/index.cgi/4273355/FID840/eqtyres/erg/111361/1361.htm | pages=198}}</ref>
== Origins ==
According to ethnologist [[Gerhard Kubik]], this tradition must be ancient and certainly pre-colonial, as observers independently collected the same ideographs among peoples separated for generations. Additionally, early [[petroglyphs]] from the [[Zambezi|Upper Zambezi]] area in Angola and Citundu-Hulu in the [[Moçâmedes Desert]] exhibit structural similarities with lusona ideographs.{{sfn|Gerhard Kubik|2006|p=229}} Those petroglyphs date from a period between the 6th century BC and the 1st-century BC.{{sfn|José Redinha|1948}}
== Usage ==
Sona ideographs are sometimes used as murals, and most of the time executed in the sand. To make them, drawing experts — after cleaning and smoothing the ground — would impress equidistant dots and draw a continuous line between them. The dots can represent trees, persons or animals, while the lines can represent paths, rivers, fences, walls, contours of a body, etc.<ref name="Hodder2013">{{cite book|author=I. Hodder|title=The Meanings of Things: Material Culture and Symbolic Expression|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T0cVAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA213|date=12 November 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-76232-4|page=210–213}}</ref>
== Mathematical properties ==
The mathematical ideas exhibited by those ideographs are [[Transformation geometry|transformational geometry]], [[abstract algebra]] and linear algebra. 80% are symmetric and 60% are mono-linear.<ref name="NessFarenga2017">{{cite book|author1=Daniel Ness|author2=Stephen J. Farenga|author3=Salvatore G. Garofalo|title=Spatial Intelligence: Why It Matters from Birth through the Lifespan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HC8lDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA56|date=12 May 2017|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-317-53118-0|page=56–57}}</ref> They are an example of the use of a coordinate system and geometric algorithms.<ref name="Elsevier BV 1991 pp. 198–198">{{cite journal | title=On mathematical elements in the Tchokwe "Sona" tradition Gerdes, Paulus. 1990. For the Learning of Mathematics10(1), 31–34 | journal=Historia Mathematica | volume=18 | issue=2 | year=1991 | issn=0315-0860 | doi=10.1016/0315-0860(91)90542-6 | url=http://webapp1.dlib.indiana.edu/virtual_disk_library/index.cgi/4273355/FID840/eqtyres/erg/111361/1361.htm | pages=198}}</ref>
=== Geometric algorithms ===
Sona drawings can be classified by the algorithms used for their construction. Paulus Gerdes identified six algorithms, most commonly the "plaited-mat" algorithm, which seems to have been inspired by mat weaving.{{sfn|Paulus Gerdes|1999|p=163-167}}
=== Chaining rules and theorems ===
Various studies suggest that the drawing experts knew specific rules of "chaining" and "elimination" relating to the systematic construction of monolinear figures. Studies suggest that the "drawing experts" who invented these rules knew why they were valid, and could prove in one way or another the validity of the theorems that these rules express.<ref name="Gerdes 1994 pp. 345–376">{{cite journal | last=Gerdes | first=Paulus | title=On mathematics in the history of Sub-Saharan Africa | journal=Historia Mathematica | volume=21 | issue=3 | year=1994 | issn=0315-0860 | doi=10.1006/hmat.1994.1029 | page=355}}</ref>
It is difficult to find accounts of theorems developed by the drawing experts to generalize specific patterns relating to dimension and monolinearity/polylinearity,<ref name="NessFarenga2017">{{cite book|author1=Daniel Ness|author2=Stephen J. Farenga|author3=Salvatore G. Garofalo|title=Spatial Intelligence: Why It Matters from Birth through the Lifespan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HC8lDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA56|date=12 May 2017|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-317-53118-0|page=56–57}}</ref> as this tradition was secret and in extinction when it started to be recorded.
However, the drawing experts possibly knew that rectangles with relatively prime dimensions give one-line drawings. This idea is supported by the fact that of the 30 smallest relatively prime rectangular shapes, 75% appears among the documented drawings. It is further possible that they knew that if a square of a dot is added to a one-line lusona, the lusona would still be mono-linear. It seems clear that they had experimentally discovered this fact for 2 X 2 squares.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.beloit.edu/computerscience/faculty/chavey/sona/ |title=Sona Geometry |last=Chavey |first=Darrah}}</ref>

{{Infobox artist | honorific_prefix = | name = Maud Lewis | honorific_suffix = | image = Maud_Lewis.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Lewis in front of her home | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = Maud Dowley | birth_date = March 7, 1903 <ref>http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/paying-tribute-to-painter-maud-lewis/</ref> | birth_place = [[South Ohio, Nova Scotia]], Canada | death_date = {{Death date and age|1970|7|30|1903|3|7}}<!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = [[Digby, Nova Scotia]], Canada | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = Canadian | education = | alma_mater = | known_for = Painting | notable_works = | style = [[Folk art]] | movement = | spouse = Everett Lewis | awards = | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = | module = }} '''Maud Kathleen Lewis''' ([[née]] '''Dowley'''; March 7, 1903 – July 30, 1970) was a Canadian [[folk artist]]<ref>[http://www.metronews.ca/news/ottawa/2015/09/14/antiques-roadshow-style-open-house-comes-to-ottawa.htmlAntiques Roadshow-style drop-in comes to Ottawa Art Gallery"]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. ''Ottawa Metro''. Haley Ritchie, Sep 14 2015</ref><ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/new-brunswick/the-snow-queen-takes-on-canadian-twist-1.2860425 "'The Snow Queen' takes on Canadian twist"]. ''CBC News'' Dec 04, 2014</ref> from [[Nova Scotia]]. Living in poverty with her husband in a small house in [[Marshalltown, Nova Scotia]], most of her life, she achieved national recognition in 1964 and 1965. Several books, plays and films have since been produced about her. Lewis remains one of Canada's best-known folk artists. Her works and the restored Maud Lewis House are displayed in the [[Art Gallery of Nova Scotia]].
==Early life== Lewis was born Maud Kathleen Dowley on March 7, 1903 in [[South Ohio, Nova Scotia|South Ohio]], Nova Scotia, the daughter of John and Agnes (Germain) Dowley.<ref name="AGN">{{cite web|title=Maud Lewis|url=http://www.artgalleryofnovascotia.ca/maud-lewis|accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref><ref>[https://www.novascotiagenealogy.com/ItemView.aspx?ImageFile=88-857&Event=marriage&ID=232219 Nova Scotia Historical Vital Statistics]</ref> She had one brother. Dowley suffered from juvenile [[rheumatoid arthritis]], which reduced her mobility, especially in her hands. Dowley was introduced to art by her mother, who instructed her in the making of watercolour Christmas cards to sell.<ref name="Maud Lewis">{{cite web|title=Digby County: A Journey Through Time|url=http://www.virtualmuseum.ca/sgc-cms/histoires_de_chez_nous-community_memories/pm_v2.php?id=story_line&lg=English&fl=0&ex=00000443&sl=8547&pos=1|website=www.virtualmuseum.ca|publisher=Virtual Museum Canada|accessdate=2015-03-07}}</ref> She began her artistic career by selling hand-drawn and painted Christmas cards.
Maud became involved with Emery Allen, also of Digby, who has been described as the love of her life. She gave birth to their daughter, Catherine Dowley, in 1928 out of wedlock. Allen abandoned Dowley and their daughter. Maud continued to live at home with her parents. It was arranged by the court for her daughter Catherine to be adopted, as Dowley had no way to support her. Later in life Catherine married Paul Muise and had her own family; they lived in Nova Scotia and Ontario. She apparently tried to contact her mother, but was not successful.<ref>Lance Woolaver, ''Maud Lewis: The Heart on the Door'' (Spencer Publishing, 2016)</ref>
In 1935, her father John died and in 1937, her mother Agnes died.<ref name="AGN" /> As was typical of the time, her brother inherited the family home. After living with her brother for a short while, Dowley moved to [[Digby, Nova Scotia]] to live with her aunt.<ref name="AGN" />
==Marriage== When Dowley was 34, she married Everett Lewis, a fish peddler from [[Marshalltown, Nova Scotia|Marshalltown]], on January 16, 1938.<ref>[http://www.digbycourier.ca/Living/2014-06-07/article-3755305/Yarmouth-promoting-its-Maud-Lewis/1 "Yarmouth promoting its Maud Lewis"]. John DeMings, ''Digby Courier'', on June 07, 2014 </ref> He also worked as the watchman at the county Poor Farm. According to Everett, Maud Dowley showed up at his door step in response to an advertisement he had posted in the local stores for a "live-in or keep house" for a forty-year-old bachelor. Several weeks later, they married.{{citation needed|date=April 2018}}
They lived in Everett's one-room house with a sleeping loft in Marshalltown, a few miles west of Digby. Maud used this house as her studio. Everett took care of the housework.<ref name="The Illuminated Life of Maud Lewis">{{cite book|last1=Woolaver|first1=Lance|title=The Illuminated Life of Maud Lewis|date=1995|publisher=Nimbus Publishing Limited|location=Halifax|isbn=1-55109-176-3|pages=16–21}}</ref> Lewis and her husband lived mostly in poverty in the one-room house. After their deaths, the house was purchased by a local group. It was acquired by the province and transferred to the [[Art Gallery of Nova Scotia]] in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]]. They had the tiny house restored and it is now part of a permanent display on Maud Lewis and her works.
Maud Lewis accompanied her husband on his daily rounds peddling fish door-to-door, bringing along Christmas cards that she had drawn. She would sell the cards for twenty-five cents each. These cards proved popular with her husband's customers, and she began painting. Everett encouraged Lewis to paint, and he bought her her first set of oils.<ref name="hamilton"/>
She expanded her range, using other surfaces for painting, such as pulp boards ([[beaverboard]]s), cookie sheets, and [[Masonite]]. Lewis was a prolific artist and also painted on more or less every available surface in their tiny home: walls, doors, breadboxes, and even the stove. She completely covered the simple patterned commercial wallpaper with sinewy stems, leaves, and blossoms.<ref name="hamilton">Laurie Hamilton, ''The Painted House of Maud Lewis'', Goose Lane Editions (2001), p. 34</ref>
==Paintings== [[File:MaudeLewisMemorial.jpg|thumb|240px|Maud Lewis Memorial in [[Marshalltown, Nova Scotia|Marshalltown]]]] Maud Lewis used bright colours in her paintings, and subjects were often flowers or animals, including oxen teams, horses, birds, deer, or cats. Many of her paintings are of outdoor scenes, including Cape Island boats bobbing on the water, horses pulling a sleigh, skaters, and portraits of dogs, cats, deer, birds, and cows. Her paintings were inspired by childhood memories of the landscape and people around [[Yarmouth, Nova Scotia|Yarmouth]] and South Ohio, as well as Digby locations, such as [[Point Prim Lighthouse|Point Prim]] and Bayview. Commercial Christmas cards and calendars also influenced her.
Most of her paintings are quite small - often no larger than eight by ten inches, although she is known to have done at least five paintings 24 inches by 36 inches. The size was limited by the extent she could move her arms, which had been affected by arthritis. She used mostly wallboard and tubes of Tinsol, an oil-based paint. Lewis' technique consisted of first coating the board with white, then drawing an outline, and applying paint directly out of the tube. She never blended or mixed colours.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Women's work : a selection of work by 4 significant Nova Scotia artists : Maria Morris, Alice Hagen, Maud Lewis, Suzanne Swannie.|journal=Mount Saint Vincent University. Art Gallery.|date=1981}}</ref>
Early Maud Lewis paintings from the 1940s are quite rare. A large collection of Lewis' work can be found in the [[Art Gallery of Nova Scotia]] (AGNS). The AGNS occasionally displays the Chaplin/Wennerstrom shutters (now part of the Clearwater Fine Foods Inc. collection). This collection comprises twenty-two exterior house shutters that Lewis painted in the early 1940s. The work was done for some Americans who owned a cottage on the [[Southern Nova Scotia|South Shore]]. Most of the shutters are quite large, at 5 ft x 1 ft.6 inches. Lewis was paid 70 cents a shutter.
Between 1945 and 1950, people began to stop at Lewis' Marshalltown home on [[Nova Scotia Trunk 1|Highway No. 1]], the main highway and tourist route in western Nova Scotia. They bought her paintings for two or three dollars each. Only in the last three or four years of Lewis' life did her paintings begin to sell for seven to ten dollars. She achieved national attention as a folk artist following an article in the Toronto-based ''[[Star Weekly]]'' in 1964. In 1965, she was featured on CBC-TV's ''[[Telescope (TV series)|Telescope]]''.<ref>{{YouTube | id=ryqC0Tz5N4Q | title= '''CBC ''Telescope''''' (1965).}}</ref> Two of Lewis' paintings were ordered by the [[White House]] in the 1970s during [[Richard Nixon]]'s presidency.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Woolaver|first1=Lance|title=The Illuminated Life of Maud Lewis|date=1995|publisher=Nimbus Publishing/Art Gallery of Nova Scotia|isbn=1-55109-176-3|page=XVII}}</ref> But, her arthritis limited her ability to complete many of the orders that had come from her national recognition.
In the early 21st century, her paintings have sold at auction for ever increasing prices. Two of her paintings have sold for more than $16,000. The highest auction price so far is $22,200.00 for lot 196 ''A Family Outing''. The painting was sold at a Bonham's auction in Toronto on November 30, 2009. Another painting, ''A View of Sandy Cove'', sold in 2012 for $20,400.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Barnard|first1=Elissa|title=Maud Lewis work fetches $20,000|url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/artslife/201208-maud-lewis-work-fetches-20000|work=Halifax Chronicle-Herald|date=28 November 2012}}</ref> A painting found in 2016 at an Ontario thrift store, ''Portrait of Eddie Barnes and Ed Murphy, Lobster Fishermen'', sold at auction for almost three times its estimated price. The online auction ended May 19, 2017, and the painting, which was appraised at $16,000, sold for $45,000.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/maud-lewis-painting-found-in-thrift-store-sells-for-45000-in-auction/article35074481/|title=Maud Lewis painting found in thrift store sells for $45,000|last=Germano|first=Daniela|date=2017-05-20|work=The Globe and Mail|access-date=2018-03-24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
==Later life and death== In the last year of her life, Maud Lewis stayed in one corner of her house, painting as often as she could while traveling back and forth to the hospital for treatment of health issues. She died in Digby on July 30, 1970 from pneumonia. <ref>[http://www.thevanguard.ca/Living/2015-08-04/article-4235517/Ferry-carried-21,000-passengers-between-Yarmouth-and-Portland-in-July-1970/1 "45 Years ago"]. ''The Vanguard''. Eric Bourque, 04 August 2015</ref> Her husband Everett was killed in 1979 by a burglar during an attempted robbery at the small house.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Woolaver|first1=Lance|title=The Illuminated Life of Maud Lewis|date=1995|publisher=Nimbus Publishing/Art Gallery of Nova Scotia|isbn=1-55109-176-3|page=81}}</ref>
==Legacy and honours== *After Everett Lewis died, the painted house began to deteriorate. A group of concerned citizens from the Digby area started the Maud Lewis Painted House Society; their goal was to save this landmark. In 1984, the house was sold to the [[Province of Nova Scotia]] and transferred to the care of [[Art Gallery of Nova Scotia]] (AGNS) in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]].<ref name="AGN" /> The AGNS restored the house and installed it as the Maud Lewis House in the gallery, as part of a permanent Lewis exhibit.<ref name="AGN" />
*A steel memorial sculpture based on her house has been erected at the original homesite in Marshalltown. It was designed by architect [[Brian MacKay-Lyons]].<ref name="replica"/> *A replica of the Maud Lewis House was built in 1999 by retired fisherman Murray Ross, complete with finished interior. It is located a few kilometres north of Marshalltown on the road to [[Digby Neck]] in Seabrook.<ref name="replica">{{cite news|last1=Whitehead|first1=Jeanne|title=Renewed appreciation for Maud Lewis replica|url=http://www.digbycourier.ca/Living/2008-12-03/article-610631/Renewed-appreciation-for-Maud-Lewis-replica/1|accessdate=5 March 2016|work=The Digby Courier|date=Dec 3, 2008}}</ref>
==Further reading and other media== Maud Lewis is the subject of a book by [[Lance Woolaver]], ''The Illuminated Life of Maud Lewis'', and three [[National Film Board of Canada]] documentaries: ''Maud Lewis - A World Without Shadows'' (1976),<ref name=withoutshadows>{{cite web|title=Maud Lewis: A World Without Shadows|url=http://www.nfb.ca/film/maud_lewis_a_world_without_shadows/|work=Online documentary|publisher=[[National Film Board of Canada]]|accessdate=18 March 2011|format=Requires [[Adobe Flash]]|year=1976}}</ref> ''The Illuminated Life of Maud Lewis'' (1998), and ''I Can Make Art ... Like Maud Lewis'' (2005). The latter is a short film in which a group of Grade 6 students are inspired by Lewis' work to create their own folk art painting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfb.ca/film/i_can_make_art_like_maud_lewis|title=I Can Make Art ... Like Maud Lewis|last=Churchill|first=Jane|year=2005|publisher=National Film Board of Canada|accessdate=2009-03-26}}</ref>
*In 2009, the Art Gallery of Nova Scotia, in conjunction with Greg Thompson Productions, produced a new play about Lewis on stage at the AGNS. ''A Happy Heart: The Maud Lewis Story'' was written and produced by Greg Thompson, who had produced ''Marilyn: Forever Blonde'' at the AGNS in January 2008. Thompson wrote the one-woman play about Lewis while in Nova Scotia in 2008. The play ran until October 25, 2009.
*Screenwriter [[Sherry White]] wrote a script for a feature dramatic film about Lewis, entitled ''[[Maudie (film)|Maudie]]'' (2016).<ref>{{cite news|title=Maudie explores folk artist’s love for another N.S. outsider|url=http://thechronicleherald.ca/artslife/1271535-maudie-explores-folk-artist%E2%80%99s-love-for-another-n.s.-outsider|work=Halifax Chronicle-Herald|date=26 February 2015}}</ref> ''Maudie'' made its Canadian debut at the [[2016 Toronto International Film Festival]]. The film was directed by [[Aisling Walsh]], and stars [[Sally Hawkins]] as Maud and [[Ethan Hawke]] as Everett Lewis.<ref>{{cite web|title=Maudie|url=http://www.tiff.net/films/maudie/|publisher=Toronto International Film Festival|accessdate=2 May 2017}}</ref>
